name: NPR
text:
President Trump rejected calls to disband or defund police departments. 

But he said, "We're going to talk about ideas how we can do it better and how we can do it if possible in a much more gentle fashion."
https://t.co/2VWVXTJq9c

name: NPR
text:
President Trump will hit the campaign trail this month — despite the deadly coronavirus pandemic, which continues to impact the lives and livelihoods of households across the country.

"The rallies will be tremendous," a campaign manager said. 
https://t.co/hZ1nV45d00

name: NPR
text:
The pandemic has already sent unemployment into double-digit territory and a coronavirus recession would be the second — or even third — economic downturn in many millennials' adult lives.
https://t.co/GLMgrqi7tp

name: NPR
text: Moscow — the epicenter of Russia's coronavirus pandemic — is lifting lockdown restrictions as the Kremlin prepares for a massive military parade and a referendum on term limits.  https://t.co/3rFN69YlGC

name: NPR
text: If you look at how housing segregation works in America, you can see how things ended up this way. And once you see… https://t.co/r6xZbvwyeb

name: NPR
text:
Protesters in Bristol, U.K., tore down a statue of infamous slave trader Edward Colston.

"It was just incredibly poetic the way that he was dragged across the city and essentially thrown overboard into the water," one organizer said. 
https://t.co/sd2qTeQnJS

name: NPR
text: Experts stress that those riding elevators should wear masks, stay in your corner, face the wall and use items such as disposable tissues or toothpicks to touch the buttons. Also, use hand sanitizer frequently. https://t.co/BHEPW8BPr7

name: NPR
text:
Workers swinging on ropes will remove around 200 tons of damaged scaffolding from the exterior of Notre Dame cathedral.

"It is an extremely complicated, very delicate operation," Christophe-Charles Rousselot of the Notre-Dame Foundation said. https://t.co/NxKgDuvwSo

name: NPR
text:
New York's legislature passed new police reform legislation Monday — including a ban on chokeholds, a prohibition on race-based profiling, and a measure requiring police departments and courts to track arrests by race and ethnicity.
https://t.co/AssIA1HHIB

name: NPR
text:
In a joint open letter, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer urged President Trump to reopen Lafayette Square after barricades were erected around it following recent protests.
https://t.co/OHNeDTz61l

name: NPR
text:
"We encourage all those protesting around the world to do so safely," said WHO director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus. 

"Clean your hands, cover your cough and wear a mask if you attend a protest."
https://t.co/oL820MJFCk

name: NPR
text:
Can't sleep? @NPRLifeKit can help with that. From experts, here are some tips on getting deep, restful sleep:

💤  Use calming mental imagery
💤  Try meditation apps
💤  Keep your bedroom cool
💤  Don't count sheep
💤  Learn good sleep hygiene https://t.co/FRtWum1ZZG

name: NPR
text:
The hip-hop duo Run the Jewels' albums have always seemed to capture the mood during times of upheaval, from the acquittal of George Zimmerman to the 2016 election. 

Their newest album, "RTJ4," recorded well before the protests, is no exception. https://t.co/khtbxCIn88

name: NPR
text: Barricades have completely blocked off parks around the White House, which had hosted constitutionally protected protests for more than 100 years. @[WAMU 88.5 - American University Radio] https://t.co/g8XpyPnUcJ

name: NPR
text:
Louisville youth pressed Mayor Greg Fischer on why he waited so long to speak out on Breonna Taylor's killing.

"Are you tired because you've been going through s*** for a couple days?" one person asked. "We tired. We go through this s*** every day."
https://t.co/BG3Au8tm2U

name: NPR
text:
COVID-19 cases in Florida are back on the rise — leading to worries that relaxed guidelines could lead to new outbreaks and even a second wave of infections.
https://t.co/YsqCvI5mC7

name: NPR
text:
The University of Alabama has removed plaques honoring students who served in the Confederate Army and student cadet corps — and the school's trustees say they will review the names of campus buildings.
https://t.co/Pr5IHaaqfn

name: NPR
text:
President Trump is set to begin holding large political rallies this month, despite the ongoing pandemic. His campaign did not comment on the specifics of safety protocols.
https://t.co/Qros8DtDha

name: NPR
text:
Texas reported a record-breaking number of COVID-19 hospitalizations Monday, as Gov. Greg Abbott moves forward with plans to reopen more businesses and double capacity.
https://t.co/UfRnMSJscj

name: NPR
text:
Mickey Guyton has spent years reaching for a mainstream breakthrough in a country music industry willing to embrace hip-hop sounds — but not black artists. 

Her new song "Black Like Me" is a statement: 

She's ready to do things her way. https://t.co/pAc5BinfJc

name: NPR
text:
The editor-in-chief of Bon Appétit, Adam Rapoport, stepped down after a photo surfaced of him in brownface — adding to accusations of discrimination and lack of inclusiveness at the magazine.
https://t.co/cekbSboCKW

name: NPR
text:
Thousands of protesters who have been arrested in Los Angeles for violating curfew or failing to disperse will not be prosecuted, county and city officials announced Monday.
https://t.co/Fl1FmkFiFA

name: NPR
text:
Funding for local law enforcement has increasingly been coming from the federal government, through an array of federal agencies.

But some experts say that undermines community accountability — and focuses more on enforcement than on minimizing harm.
https://t.co/VIN3n9ByPb

name: NPR
text:
Growing evidence finds that people with developmental or intellectual disabilities have higher rates of death from COVID-19.

In New York state, people with developmental disabilities die at 2.5 times the rate of others who contract the virus.
https://t.co/9ZHJhdHw8I

name: NPR
text:
In March, the EPA told companies they didn't need to warn federal regulators if the pandemic interferes with routine pollution monitoring or testing.

That put states alone on the front lines of environmental protection —even as they grapple with COVID-19.
https://t.co/80am9YQYDn

name: NPR
text:
George Floyd will be laid to rest today in his hometown of Houston. His family's private service follows public memorials that drew thousands of mourners.
https://t.co/bjOrH27cge

name: NPR
text: Video: Family and friends gather at The Fountain of Praise in Houston, to pay respects to George Floyd, who was killed by police in Minneapolis on Memorial Day. https://t.co/pEycb0HxVN

name: NPR
text:
NPR sifted through a database of federal contracts granted to fight COVID-19.

More than 250 companies got contracts worth over $1 million, without going through a fully competitive bidding process.

Some had little or no medical supply experience.
 https://t.co/tOhvydMKDF

name: NPR
text: 2020 is '68 all over again. But not the '68 you think. On a new episode of @NPRItsBeenaMin host @samsanders speaks with Adam Serwer from The Atlantic about how 1868 is a more comparable year than 1968. https://t.co/XgpxMMPQSE

name: NPR
text:
Bonnie Pointer, the Grammy-winning singer and songwriter who was a founding member of the Pointer Sisters, has died at the age of 69.
https://t.co/rY8Xcw4Wbz

name: NPR
text:

https://t.co/4nHLURXcIi https://t.co/iAsiaCwI54

text: “I leave with you one word, his final word, which was breathe,” said Ivy McGregor, Parkwood Entertainment's social… https://t.co/rJbKbwOAPo

text:

https://t.co/U7963uXSDg

text:
